content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good and fun puzzle, good test coverage, clear instructions. Well done!

I liked it, it works fine.
Both a quick and fun challenge

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple puzzle that serves as a good introduction to how CPUs work.

Hi @YALOKGAR, must the first operation always be a MOV operation? Is it possible to construct programs that, e.g., perform a DEC operation on a register, or e.g. immediately terminates?

Please also include some test cases where the MOV operation is used on a register containing some non-zero value. Thank you :)
Ok for me!

* The "Register Swap" case doesn't actually swap the values. Is this intentional?
* HLT instructions only appear at the end of programs in current test cases. Is this intentional?
* Consider adding a test/validator pair for V=FF to verify it isn't incorrectly consumed as a HLT instruction. Currently, this is only checked by the "INC Overflow" (test) case.

Thank you.

Goal
* R0 to R3 are concrete register names, RX and RY are symbolic variables, and XX and YY are raw byte values. Since the statement doesn't define how XX/YY map to RX/RY, the reader is forced to infer the relationship. Please explicitly clarify the mapping in the statement.

* Please add a note clarifying that the 0x prefixes are used for readability only and are not part of the actual input.

Output
* Please add ", one value per line" to the end.

Constraints
* The closing bracket is missing in the third constraint.

Stub generator
* Please remove all language-specific remarks, as solvers are free to choose languages other than C.

Difficulty
* As mentioned by @yhuberla, it's more appropriate to grade the puzzle as Easy.

Cases
* Each test and its validator should cover the same scenario. Currently:

  • Opcode 00x3 is only covered by Validator 1 and not by any visible tests.

  • 00x5 overflow is only covered in Test 4 and not by any validators.

  Please revise the existing cases to ensure test/validator alignment.

* Overflow and underflow in these situations aren't covered in any cases:
  • 00x2 overflow
  • 00x3 underflow
  • 00x4 overflow
  • 00x6 underflow

  Please add new pairs of cases to cover the missing scenarios. Ensure that at least one test and at least one validator covers each of the scenarios.

Thanks.

This is my jam.

I would grade this puzzle like https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/compiler-cg86-easy-version which is in the easy category.

Please add a closing parenthesis in the Constraints after (0xFF.

The information in STATEMENT in the stub generator is specific to C and C++ languages, which a majority of solvers won't be using.

I get the same outputs as you on the test cases.

Fixed closing parenthesis in Constraints (0xFF)
Changed difficulty to Easy
Removed C/C++ specific hints from stub generator

Appreciate the feedback!
Also, registers 2 and 3 are used in Validator 2 only, but not in any other cases. The coverage is very unbalanced.

Renamed to "Arithmetic Variant"

Adding early HLT would change the scope of the puzzle

V=FF coverage Added

Thanks for the review!

Hey! MOV doesn’t have to be the first instruction everything starts at 0, so starting with INC/DEC is fine. And yep, a program can be just FF to stop immediately. I tweaked the statement to make that explicit and added a couple cases (including one where MOV overwrites a register that was already non‑zero).

I don't think you need to clarify that in the statement! Probably better to let players figure it out as they run through the test cases :) But I'm ok with the statement either way.

Just a minor fix, please modify the first constraint to: 2 ≤ Program length ≤ 100 bytes. Thank you!
No. but thx for feedback

Thanks for the thorough review! All changes applied

Added explicit mapping X and Y are register indices (0-3), V is immediate byte value

Opcodes shown without 0x prefix (matches input format)

Added "one value per line"

Fixed closing parenthesis

Removed all language-specific remarks

Changed to Easy per @yhuberla's suggestion

Ready for re-review!
Coverage is now balanced across all 4 registers.

The puzzle is in much better shape now.

Goal
* Please format "01" to "06" and "FF" as {{constants}}.

Constraints
* Please add:
For the opcodes {{02}}, {{03}} and {{04}}, [[X]] ≠ [[Y]].

Cases
* These cases are the same:
  • DEC Underflow (Test 5)
  • ADD Overflow (Test 6)
  
  The ADD Overflow input seems wrong.

* Please add a pair of new cases where normal, overflow and underflow calculations all occur, and all 4 registers have non-zero value at the end. Please do NOT reuse any [[X]]/[[Y]] combinations from the existing cases. Instead, please include instructions where [[X]] > [[Y]] and instructions where abs([[X]] - [[Y]]) > 1.

Thanks.

Formatted opcodes as {{constants}}: {{01}} through {{06}} and {{FF}}

Added For the opcodes {{02}}, {{03}} and {{04}}, [[X]] = [[Y]]

Fixed Test 5 vs Test 6 mismatch (had copied wrong input to form)

Added Test 9 + Validator 9

Ready for re-review!
I don't have any comments for now. Thank you for your prompt follow-up.
Thanks for the feedback)
